newsitem.title: FRANCE: Santer says Paris could have softened Renault blow.
newsitem.headline: Santer says Paris could have softened Renault blow.

text.p: European Commission President Jacques Santer said on Sunday the French government could have intervened to prevent car-maker Renault from suddenly closing a big Belgian plant and laying off 3,100 workers.
Santer told France-2 television in an interview that the way Renault announced its decision had dealt a serious blow to the spirit of European unity.
The centre-right government, main shareholder in Renault, "could definitely have intervened" through its representatives on the management board.

"The spirit of confidence which is the very basis of European construction, which aims to be not only a market but also a market based on a certain solidarity and on social cohesion, has definitely suffered a serious blow," Santer said.
"It is not within the spirit of European directives to not inform or consult workers to try and reach an agreement, even if it on accompanying measures," Santer added.
Renault car workers staged brief strikes in several countries on Friday as the fallout over plans to close the Vilvoorde plant with the loss of 3,100 jobs spread.
